skill.name: tmux-processes
skill.description: Patterns for running long-lived processes in tmux. Use when starting dev servers, watchers, tilt, or any process expected to outlive the conversation.
skill.summary: Patterns for running long-lived processes in tmux. Use when starting dev servers, watchers, tilt, or...
skill.author: 0xBigBoss

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown patterns and best practices for tmux process management. No executable code, no file access, no network calls, no external command execution. All documented capabilities directly match the stated purpose of managing long-lived dev processes.

content.value_statement: Managing long-running processes across Claude Code sessions can be challenging. This skill provides patterns for starting dev servers, watchers, and other persistent processes in tmux sessions that survive conversation reloads.
actual_capabilities: Start dev servers in detached tmux sessions
Add multiple windows for parallel processes (server, tests, logs)
limitations: Requires tmux to be installed on the system
Only manages processes within tmux, not other process managers
No built-in process health monitoring or auto-restart
Session names derive from git root or pwd only

use_cases.title: Run dev server with hot reload
use_cases.description: Start a dev server in tmux that persists across Claude Code session reloads while you work on the frontend.

use_cases.title: Manage Tilt development environments
use_cases.description: Keep Tilt up and running in tmux with proper session isolation to avoid conflicts with other projects.

use_cases.title: Monitor multiple services simultaneously
use_cases.description: Run server, tests, and logs in separate tmux windows within one session for parallel visibility.

prompt_templates.title: Start Dev Server
prompt_templates.prompt: Start a dev server for this project in tmux. Use the project name for the session and create a 'server' window. Run 'npm run dev' or the appropriate dev command.

prompt_templates.title: Check Status
prompt_templates.prompt: Check if the tmux session for this project exists and list all windows. Report which processes are running in each window.

prompt_templates.title: Add Process Window
prompt_templates.prompt: Add a new window to the current tmux session for running tests in watch mode. Use the project session name, create a window named 'tests', and run 'npm run test:watch' or the equivalent test command.
prompt_templates.description: Add a new window to the current tmux session for running tests in watch mode. Use 'npm run test:watch' or equivalent.

prompt_templates.title: View Logs
prompt_templates.prompt: Capture the last 50 lines of output from the server window. Look for any errors or ready messages.

best_practices: Always derive session name from git root (git rev-parse --show-toplevel) or pwd to ensure isolation
Use send-keys pattern to run commands in interactive shell for proper PATH/direnv initialization
Check if session exists before starting to avoid duplicate processes
anti_patterns: Using inline command execution (new-session -d 'command') which bypasses shell initialization
Using kill-server which terminates ALL tmux sessions including other users' sessions
Killing sessions without verifying the session name matches the current project

faq.question: Does this skill require tmux to be installed?
faq.answer: Yes, tmux must be installed on the system. Install via package manager (apt, brew, yum) before using.

faq.question: Can I run processes from multiple projects simultaneously?
faq.answer: Yes, each project gets its own tmux session with a unique name derived from the project directory.

faq.question: What happens when I restart Claude Code?
faq.answer: Tmux sessions persist independently. Processes continue running and you can reconnect using the same session name.

faq.question: Is my code or data at risk when using this skill?
faq.answer: No. This skill only manages terminal sessions. It does not read, modify, or transmit code or data.

faq.question: Why use tmux instead of running processes directly?
faq.answer: Tmux sessions survive Claude Code session reloads. Processes continue running without blocking the conversation.

faq.question: Can I use this skill on Windows or macOS?
faq.answer: Tmux works on Linux and macOS. On Windows, use WSL2, Git Bash, or Cygwin with tmux installed.
